metadata.subject: Is US data as good as it looks? Is Chinese data as bad as it looks? Is European data as bizarre as it looks?

relationships.description: Chief Investment Officer of J.P. Morgan Private Bank
ECB provided 650 billion Euros to EU banks
Chinese GDP growth fuels economic activity in Asia

analysis.purpose: To provide market commentary and economic analysis to clients/investors about global economic conditions
analysis.significance: Comprehensive analysis of major global economies (US, Europe, China) during post-2008 financial crisis recovery period

notable_quotes: "What a diff'rence a day makes. Ever since the ECB giftwrapped 650 billion Euros for EU banks, the news has been pretty good, particularly in the US."
"I lose a lot of sleep over this [US primary budget deficit], but I don't know a lot of other people that do."
"Comparing the rigor of US and European bank stress tests is like comparing the rigors of actual football to Wii football."
red_flags: European bank deleveraging of 3 trillion Euros
High housing price to income ratios in Chinese cities exceeding peak 2006 California levels

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this economic analysis document

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed - this is legitimate economic analysis and market commentary

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be a standard market commentary report that would be distributed to J.P. Morgan clients, containing economic analysis that would be of interest to financial media and investors

analysis.summary: This J.P. Morgan market commentary from March 2012 analyzes global economic conditions, noting improving US job markets and consumer spending despite concerns about budget deficits, ongoing challenges in European economies outside Germany, and China's economic slowdown with potential for government stimulus to reinvigorate growth.
